text:
- Before we begin, maybe
actually just to catch us up,

can you tell a bit about Bria AI,
what problems you're trying
to solve, and we'll take it from there?

- Yeah, so we are building
a platform for developers,

but for... Basically
building for enterprises.
So enterprises can actually
unlock the great premise of GenAI.

So we're trying to
solve the basic problems

that in their adoption by
enterprises like responsibility,
privacy, inclusion, biases.
- And this is specifically what kind

of GenAI applications
are we thinking of?

- Yeah, so we mainly focus
on the creative space.

So we have image generation,
image modification.

We're now going to issue
our first motion.
Text to motion model.

And this year is also to going
to see our first video model.
Nice. Actually,
so that means you are training a lot
of computer vision models
and I know my team tells me
that you're training them on SageMaker and

but to start listing them
on things like SageMaker,
Jumpstart and so forth.

And I would love to know what
are some of the experiences
on SageMaker
and then why you're thinking about
listing on Jumpstart and Bedrock,

and would love to see what
your thoughts are?
We would like to say that we are
SageMaker native

because all our models are
trained to date on SageMaker.

This has been a very
powerful environment for us

and we also think that it's
really a very good environment

for our customers to
take their models off.

And this is why we're launching
this quarter on Jumpstart.

- Nice. And with Jumpstart,
they should be able
to bring their own data sets
or how should they think about this?

If I'm a developer who wants
to build a GenAI application,

what are the things
that they can do with?

- Yeah, so one of the pillars
upon which Bria was built is
that we only train our models on data
that was licensed from our data partners.
So we license data from Getty Images

Envato, Alamy and Deposit photos,
almost 20 data partners

and almost 1 billion images
under contract explicitly
licensed for GenAI training.

So for us respecting the privacy
of this data, the IP rights
and this data is very important.

The same for the proprietary
data used by our customers

to inform our models for fine
tuning and so on and so forth.

So SageMaker is really, I
would say, synergetic to all
of what we offer.

- Because data scientists are
so used to that environment

that they should be able to
put together with that data

and customize it is really
how you're thinking about it.
Okay. No, that makes sense.

I know actually innovating
in this space, especially

with something like computer
vision actually also there are
so many applications and potentials,
but given we are in Europe

and I would love to
actually say regulation
is always on top of mind for me.
How do you think about responsible AI

and what are some of the
things that is on top of mind

for you and how are you
enabling your customers to

build AI applications
in a responsible manner?

- Yeah. So I think you
are among the few people

that can appreciate the
following statement.

Four and a half years ago when
we started to try to explain

to people that we're going
to generate images out
of thin air was difficult enough.

Yeah? Add to this that we
also said from inception
that we're going to do this responsibly.

Respecting copyrights,
privacy, safety.

It was just, "Okay, you
have to be committed." Right?

Now, I think the market
is really catching up,
I would say, with our initial vision

and for us regulation, you
know, it was inevitable

because at the end, AI is
built on three pillars, right?
It's the compute,
it's the AI expertise, and the content.

And all we're
doing is something that
for us from the start was very trivial.

You have to compensate
all the participants

in this joint endeavor.
And this is what we try to do.
And we created attribution technology.

We have five patents for this
technology.

And we're able to attribute
each synthetic image

that is being generated
by any of our models

to the original data owners,
in the training data set

that impacted the most,
this specific generation.

And we don't stop there, we
also allocate the revenue

that is coming toward this
specific synthetic generation
with the original images.
- That's actually quite powerful,

especially when you think about
what developers can do with
that kind of... having that data from
one lineage and so forth.

It actually unlocks a whole
different ecosystem.
Amazing innovation.
I just want to say thanks again actually

for being an amazing customer
and a partner as well.

And really looking
forward to figuring out

how we can jointly enable
so much innovation together.
Thank you.

- Amazing. Thank
you for your partnership.
Really appreciate your support.
